Dear Miss Zeger,

As I estate in the questionshire my wife and I left Old England in 1903 to come to Canada. Our friends said we were crazy to leave a good home and well established business to go to the north pole a land that was nothing but ice and snow where babies cheeks froze to the pillows and where wild animals abounded. Our first house was built of poplar logs rooted with poplar poles hay and sod then I put on a two inch covering of clay, this roof turned water for three years and then the cats started to claw holes in it and started leaks.

Our first baby was born in this house on the 5th of April 1906, the Doctor being brought from Battleford 25 miles away. Our furniture consisted of store boxes and our first arm chair was an apple barrel with the sides cut down and filled with prairie soil hay, and many happy hours have we and others spent therein.

I started farming with a team of oxen, they were green and so was I but I soon learned that to get along with oxen one had to have lots of patience with a great big capital P, later I traded them off for a team of mares and then things went along faster. Our first crop was 6 acres of oats sown broadcast from the back of a wagon, they made wonderful growth and as this was a free range country I had to start in and fence them, while I was doing this Mr. Hitchins came along with a bunch of cattle about 60 head and they tramped right over my 5 inch high crop of oats I felt like crying, Mr. H said "On that wont hurt the oats that is what they need to make them grow and he was right for when they were thrashed by a horse power thrasher Mr. Rater and I homesteaded in Baljennie and were good friends and neighbour from then until now, his eldest son Charles Hedley still farms in Baljennie, Arthur James the youngest son is now the Member.

Our furniture consisted of store boxes and our first arm chair was an apple barrel with the sides cut down and filled with prairie wold hay, and many happy hours have we and others spent therein.

I started farming with a team of oxen, they were green and so was I but I soon learned that to get along with oxen one had to have lots of patience with a great big capital. Later I traded them off for a team of mares and then things went along faster, our first crop was 6 acres of oats grown broadcast from the back of a wagon, they made wonderful growth and as this was a free range country I had to start in and fence them, while I was doing this Mr. Hitchins came along with his 5 inch high crop of oats I felt like crying, Mr. H said "Oh that wont hurt the oats that is what they need to make them grow and he was right for when they were thrashed by a horse power thresher..."
they yielded over 75 bushels to the acre. My first job on a thresher in Canada was on the horse power platform with a long whip to keep the horses moving, that made me dizzy and I had to quit so the boss put me to cutting bands and at that I evidently gave satisfaction for he kept me at it. In 1913 I bought my first thrashing machine a small outfit 8hp engine and separator on the same trucks, this little outfit did good for 10 years then as custom acreage got larger I traded it an on a larger outfit and got a IO-20 tractor and an International separator 28-36.

By this time I had my son to help and we did a great amount of custom work, and then I again traded the IO-20 in on a IS-30 T.H.C., In the falls of 1945 and 1946 help was so scarce and my son being engaged at the University I did my own threshing, I set the machind in the field went and got a load of sheaves on the rack hauled it to the machine and threshed it and then went and got another load and so on and finished up in a snow storm, 90 acres of homestead was broken and backed with a 14 inch walking plow, and from 1904 until 1912 I walked behind three sections of harrows when I bought my first harrow cart.

When we first moved on to the homestead we lived in a bell tent and having no stove we had to do our cooking on an open fire outside. It came on to rain heavy and kept it up for three days and three nights without a letup, during this time we heated water for tea and porridge over a stable lantern and I can recollect this as a patient proceeding, at this time we also had a guest a wet and bedraggled sparrow which stayed with us all the time it rained. After the rain Mr. Hitchins came to see how we were faring and asked us to go and work for him and we did so and lived there until July 1904 when we moved onto our homestead.

When we first moved on to the homestead we lived in a bell tent and having no stove we had to do our cooking on an open fire outside. It came on to rain heavy and kept it up for three days and three nights without a letup, during this time we heated water for tea and porridge over a stable lantern and I can recollect this as a patient proceeding, at this time we also had a guest a wet and bedraggled sparrow which stayed with us all the time it rained. After the rain Mr. Hitchins came to see how we were faring and asked us to go and work for him and we did so and lived there until July 1904 when we moved onto our homestead.
We lived in the tent for about 6 weeks and during that time we were often bothered by cattle rubbing their heads on the tent pegs. During this period of time I was breaking prairie building the house of logs and a stable all at the same time when breaking the prairie hay was so thick that the sod flopped back and I had to go back and turn it over. Eventually I got the house high enough and with the roof on so we could move into it which we did with the cellar hole only half covered, no windows as yet and with a blanket for a door when I got lumber for a door I took the hinges off one of the boxes that we had brought from the Old Country we had no cash for locks but we had the old style latch string if we wanted to lock the door we just pulled the latch string inside. This first log house is still in use but with a better roof and used as a granary.

During the early years we often had a visit from the R.N.W.M. Police, they would be on patrol duty from Battleford (not North Battleford) and we were always glad to see them and have them stay for a meal, they came to see how we duffers were getting along at "farming" they were all good fellows.

The Barr colonists arrived in Saskatoon on April 17 1903 about 11am in the first contingent there was about 500 and the second train brought in another 400 about 6pm. The first lot went to the tents that had been erected for them but the second lot had to stay in the train all night.

On our way out west we became acquainted with one of the colonists Mr. W.H. Rater and his two sons they were from Cornwall, Eng.; and were on their way to the Barr colony but both Mr. Rater and I homesteaded in Baljennie and were good friends and neighbours from then until now, his eldest son Charles Hedley still farms in Baljennie, Arthur James the youngest son is now the Member...

Mr. J.H. Megaffin, mentioned on page 39 in the current issue of Saskatchewan History - is another near neighbour of mine and has been from 1903 until the time of my retirement to Saskatoon and I am well acquainted with all members of his family and I can substantiate Mrs (Cle) Bright's assertion that her mother baked 40 loaves a day when the Barrittes were passing their house on their way to the colony, no one ever went in need of a meal at Jim Megaffins, he was a good friend to we early settlers, and no woman in the west worked harder than Mrs. Megaffin.

In conclusion I can only say that we are quite satisfied with our decision in coming to Canada.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires

( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

Note: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct and you have evidence to the contrary, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Harrison Herbert Marsden.
2. Your address: 1502 Broadway Ave., Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
3. Date: September 7th, 1958.
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   33 Bradford Rd., Manchester, Lancashire, England.
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   Mark Harrison, Butcher.
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   April 5th, 1903.
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   None.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child" if you were five years old.)
   I was 23 years of age.
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   The damp climate of northern England caused attacks of pleurisy.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)
    I saw an advertisement in the evening paper and wrote away for information on free farms in Canada and after careful study of the pamphlets I decided to marry and come to Canada.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
They thought we were foolish to leave a good home and business to come to a land that we knew nothing about, but being brought up in the butchering trade and doing our own slaughtering, and being acquainted with animals viz: horses, cattle, sheep and pigs. I took the chance.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
We travelled by ourselves and made friends along the way.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
We booked passage by the Allen Line and sailed from Liverpool on the S.S. Bavarian on March 19th 1903.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.).
We both went through the throes of sea sickness and neither of us enjoyed it. On the 21st there was a heavy head sea and racks were put on the tables to keep dishes in place, on the 25th the sea was a lot calmer and the tickets were collected. On the 27th we were all awakened in the night by collision, with an iceberg no damage to the ship. On the 28th saw some sparrows and sighted Halifax about 10.30 am and got into dock at 1.30 pm. 2,328 miles from Liverpool. We got our baggage checked by the Customs and got into the train for Winnipeg at 11.30 pm and it started in a heavy snowstorm, owing to the novelty of the situation we only got snatches of sleep during the night. We have stood up well to the trials of the voyage, are in good health and ready for what is ahead of us.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
In Saskatoon. When we arrived we couldn't get a room anywhere so we went to the Mounted Police and Corporal and Mrs Clishby fixed up my wife and two other ladies on the guard room floor in wolf skin robes, then another man and I got in the Immigration Hall on the floor in our own blankets.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
At Baljennie, 25 miles southeast of old town of Battleford.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
We resided and worked at the ranch of Mt. Hitchins from May 27-03 1903 to July 7th 1904, when we moved onto our homestead and took up residence from then until Dec 1st 1947 (43 years) on which date we moved to Saskatoon retired by doctors orders.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
In the Old Country I was in the butchering business with my father and after I homesteaded I went in for mixed farming, and was at that until I retired.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They thought we were foolish to leave a good home and business up in the butchering trade and doing our own slaughtering and being schmoozed with animals viz: horses, cattle, sheep and pigs I took the chance.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? We travelled by ourselves and made friends along the way.

13. What means of transportation did you use? We booked passage by the Allen Line and sailed from Liverpool on the S.S. Bavarian on March 16th 1905.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, sicknesses or other excitement etc.). We both went through the throes of sea sickness and neither of us enjoyed it. On the 21st there was a heavy head sea and racks were put on the tables to keep dishes in place on the 25th the sea was a lot calmer and the tickets were collected. On the 27th we were all wakened in the night by collision with an iceberg no damage to the ship. On the 28th we saw some sparrows and sighted Halifax about 10:30 am and got into dock at 1:30 pm - 238 miles from Liverpool. We got our baggage checked by the customs and got onto the train for Winnipeg at 11:30 pm and it started in a heavy snowstorm owing to the novelty of the situation we only got snatches of sleep during the night and the next day we got well to the trials of the voyage are in good order but what is ahead of us?

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? In Saskatoon. When we arrived we couldn't get a room anywhere so we went to the Mounted Police and Corporal Mr. Clisby fixed up my wife and two other ladies on the guard from Fort Macleod to Baljennie then another meal and I got in the Immigration Hall on June 12th in our own blankets and I.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? At Baljennie 25 miles south east of old town of Battleford.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. We settled and worked at the ranch of Mr. Hutchins from May 27-05 1903 to July 7th 1904 when we moved onto our homestead and took up residence from then until Dec 1st 1949 (43 years) on which date we moved to Saskatchewan retired by doctors orders.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came? In the Old Country I was in the butchering business with my father and after I homesteaded I went in for mixed farming and was at that until I retired.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   We wrote fairly often, in the winter it helped to pass the time.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
   My wife's name was Catherine F. Crawford, we were married in St Thomas Church, Pendleton, Manchester, October 27, 1902.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
   Yes, my wife's sister and her son of 12 years.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
   No other members of our family came to Canada.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
   The first year or two were hard to get through with no money in the purse, for meat we had to live by the gun, the Mounted Police Patrol watched over new settlers and we were always glad to have them pay us a visit and join us at a meal. One morning we ate the last piece of bread for breakfast and about ten o'clock Mr Hitchins came along in a buggy and said, "I was up to Battleford yesterday and the cook oil can got a leak and some oil got on this bag of flour and the Missus won't use it do you think Mrs Harrison could use it?" I said "Yes I think she could and thank you very much", I might say there was very little oil on the flour. Mr Hitchins was a very good friend to us up to the time of his death which occurred on October 8th 1906. I was once walking over the river on the ice in early November and the ice gave way and let me through the box of groceries that I was carrying jammed in the hole and stopped me going through altogether, I scrambled out on to the ice and so along the shore, when I stood up my clothes froze. I was about four miles from home, I started to jog trot and a team caught up with me and took me home, after nights rest I was no worse.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.)
   Our means of travel was by team and wagon oft times by saddle horse say from 1903 to 1907 we had to go to Battleford for all our requirements and that was 25 miles from Baljennie. The first church services were held in Mr Hitchins house when an Anglican student Mr Maine came from Battleford on snowshoes. The first resident minister was Mr Love who lived in the old police detachment and was later moved to Quill Lake to be followed by Mr Cardwell. This gentleman was instrumental in getting a church built in Baljennie with funds donated by some ladies in Ireland who named the church St Bridgits (sad to relate this church was struck by lightning in the night of July 4th 1952 and was burnt to the ground, and was a total loss) We did most of our visiting in the winter, with the neighbours and dances, once hitching up four horses to a double sleigh box and driving 30 miles to Guiness school in 20 below zero.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

My wife's name was Catherine F. Crawford. We were married in St. Thomas Church, Pendleton, Manchester, October 27, 1902.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? It as a place to settle? My wife's sister and her son of 16 years.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

No other members of our family came to Canada.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

The first winter we had to live by the gun, the mounted police patrol watched over us. We were settlers and we were always glad to have them pay us a visit and join us at a meal.

One morning we ate the last piece of bread for breakfast and said, "We'll go to Battleford yesterday and the coal oil will run out."

I wanted to get oil on this bag of flour and the oil was very thin.

It was hard work to think Mr. Harrison could use it. I said, "Yes, I think he could."

And thank you very much, I might say, Mr. Friend.

I was walking over the river on the 20th of October 8th.

November and the ice gave way and I fell through the ice.

December 1st, I was carrying jammed in the hole and stopped.

Groceries that I was carrying scrambled out onto the ice and were lost.

24. Did you travel much in the early years? How far? By what means of travel?

With a horse and oxen I started to Jog trot and then by horse.

Four miles from home after nights rest I was caught up.

Visiting friends, etc., How often? How far?

Our means of travel was by team and wagon or by saddle horse.

Church services were held in Mr. Hitchison's house and an Anglican resident minister was Mr. Love who came from England.

Mr. Cardwell, the schoolmaster, was instructed by some Irishmen in Ireland.

Mr. Cardwell and his wife moved to Qu'Appelle and built a school in Tallekena with funds donated by some Irishmen.

Who named the church St. Bridget's? In the night of July 4th, 1925, struck by lightning and was a total loss.

We did not lose anything up to the ground, and was the neighbour and friend.

In the winter, with the neighbour and friend.

School in 20 below zero.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
The first car was brought into the district by Mr J.H. Megaffin, rancher and ex Mountie on June 25th 1915. It was a Case touring.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
I bought my first car on July 4th 1917. A Ford touring.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
Prior to 1906 we had to trade at Battleford 25 miles west of Baljennie.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
We traded at Battleford until the fall of 1906 when we then crossed the river to go to Ruddell on the C.N.R., from Saskatoon to North Battleford. This trip was only 7 miles in winter but 11 miles in summer owing to us having to cross the river on the ferry.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
Owing to distance from store not very often, and only when necessary.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
The train service from Saskatoon to Baljennie began on Oct 3, 1931 and after this date everyone started to trade at Baljennie siding which was and still is the end of steel on this branch C.P.R. line.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the company started.
Personally we didn't use the mail order catalogue very often, didn't have the cash to send, and we used it even less after the R.R came to Ruddell, the most use made of that was in the years 1903 to 1906.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
The first telephone to be installed in Baljennie was between Mr Buck the government telegraph operator and my house on barb wire fencing, about 2½ miles, built by ourselves.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
I made up my mind in the Old Country to come to Canada to make a go of farming and I think I did it. We moved on to our homestead and lived there continuously until Dec 1st 1947. On which date we left the farm with a truck load of belongings to come to this city of Saskatoon, and after nearly 5 years of city life I still think that the farm is the best place to live where the air is pure and the food is of the best, and my wife agrees with me.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?
There were not many people in Baljennie prior to 1914 and only one homesteader moved away, the reason ill health.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?
None moved away; they all stayed by their farms in spite of dry weather and poor crops.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.
I was Postmaster from July 29th 1910 until March 7th 1932.
I was Sec-Tres of the Baljennie School District #796, from early in 1910 to some time in 1929. On Sept 30th 1926, I was elected Sec-Tres of the Baljennie Development Asn, and held that office until the summer of 1946. I was appointed weed Inspector for Division 5 in the municipality of Glenside #377 and held office for 6 years, for a number of years acted as Church Warden and vestry clerk, on Aug 16th 1916, I was appointed Commissioner for Oaths and I have acted as D.R.O at elections and as Enumerator.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)
I was the first in the district to purchase a cream separator.
I was the first Sec-Tres of the Baljennie S.D #796. I took the first load of wheat to Ruddell from south of the Saskatchewan river, and I was the first to take a load of wheat into the Consolidated Elevator at Baljennie on Jan 13, 1931. I was the first Commissioner for Oaths in Baljennie, we were the first to have geese and guinea fowl in our farm yard.

The first settler there named it after his daughter Jean. Snake hill is a small hill alongside the trail to Battleford honeycombed with small holes where hundreds of snakes are to be seen starting out every spring and returning to the holes every fall.
